p: Prevention and control: There is no specific treatment for flaviviruses and disease control primarily relies on integrated virus surveillance and on vector control, with strategies and methodologies differing between European countries [ 154, 155]. However, for WNV, three equine vaccines have a European Marketing Authorization ( Table 2). The Zoetis Equip WNV vaccine is composed of the inactivated West Nile virus, strain VM-2 New York 1999 combined with an adjuvant [ 156]. The other two vaccines are recombinant and adjuvanted vaccines. Proteq West Nile is composed of a canary poxvirus vector expressing the prM and E genes of WNV [ 157]. The canarypox vector performs an abortive replication cycle in mammalian cells where the inserted gene product (transgene) is expressed [ 158]. Finally, the Equilis West Nile vaccine from Intervet consists of the yellow fever virus (YFV) 17D vaccine strain where the prM and E genes of YFV have been replaced by those of WNV. This recombinant vaccine is injected under an inactivated form [ 159]. No vaccine against TBEV and LIV are available for horses.
